Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao 266101 China Graphical abstract In this work, we report the synthesis of crystalline Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst by using different silica sources, including colloidal silica (silica sol), gelatinous silica (silica gel) and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS). These samples were characterized by various techniques (SEM, XRD, BET, ICP-OES, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, XAFS). The sample prepared by using silica sol exhibited regular morphology and uniform particle dispersions. The results also showed that different acidities and Cu ions distributions were present on these Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. The various silica sources affected the physicochemical properties and subsequent catalytic performances in the selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3 (NO-SCR). Cu-SSZ-13 from TEOS showed obvious advantage for the catalytic activity at low-temperature region (< 200 °C). However, Cu-SSZ-13 from silica gel performed superior overall catalytic activity (200–600 °C) in the three samples. Furthermore, Cu-SSZ-13 from silica sol displayed superior hydrothermal stability after the same hydrothermal treatment for the three samples, despite of the similar movement of Cu2+ ions under aging process. Thus, the choice of silica sol as precursor source is more profitable for synthesis of Cu-SSZ-13. Keywords Cu-SSZ-13 Silica sources NH3-SCR Hydrothermal stability 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) emission leads to extremely serious environmental problems, including global warming, acid rain and smog [1–3]. Stationary coal fired boiler and mobile vehicle emissions are main sources of the nitrogen oxides [2]. To meet the stringent emission standards [4], many approaches, such as low nitrogen combustion, exhaust gas recycling (EGR) in engine, as well as post-treatment NH3-SCR [5], NH3-SCO [6] and other technologies were developed to eliminate NOx (deNOx) in the past decades. Now, as an economic and effective method for deNOx, NH3-SCR has flourished [1,7]. The catalyst plays central role in high efficiency SCR reaction. There are many kinds of NH3-SCR catalysts, from metal oxides to zeolite (normally coating on cordierite honeycomb). With typical metal oxide (V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2) as catalyst, some disadvantages are difficult to avoid, such as the narrow active temperature range, the poor low temperature activity [8], and the environment toxic vanadium [9,10]. In comparison, zeolites can roughly overcome these problems. Recently, Fe or Cu ions exchanged zeolites BEA, ZSM-5, SAPO-34 and SSZ-13 have received wide attention due to their superb SCR activity and N2 selectivity. Among them, Cu-SSZ-13 possesses relatively wide temperature window, superb SCR activity, N2 selectivity, excellent hydrothermal stability and superior SO2 resistance after ion exchange with copper [11,12]. SSZ-13 was the first CHA-type aluminosilicate synthesized by Zones [13]. The preparation of Cu-SSZ-13 is affected by a variety synthesis of conditions, such as the composition of the precursor (silica source, aluminum source, Si/Al ratio [14], organic structure templating agent, water content, alkalinity, seed crystal [15]), aging time, static or dynamic crystallization, crystallization temperature and time, the amount of Cu2+ loading (type of Cu2+, ion change temperature and time), etc. The formation of zeolite has a considerable relationship with the type of silica source of the precursor [16]. It has been shown that the silica source may control the nucleation and crystallization processes, by forming different size of aluminosilicate intermediates as well as primary nucleus to final crystals. The final size and morphology of the zeolite nanocrystals were found to be highly depending on the silica source [17]. There are some reports on the growth mechanisms of synthetic SSZ-13. For example, during hydrolysis of TEOS in basic structure directing agent (SDA) solution, small nanoaggregates, often called primary nucleus, are formed and involved at the first stage of zeolite. At least another condensation/aggregation stage forms the secondary nanoparticles [18]. A suitable arrangement by sharing 8 rings and then coupling to form smaller 8-double 6-ring units forms a viable core for the CHA molecular sieve [18–20]. The morphology and final crystal size are decided at last accordingly. However, the effect of silica source is rarely studied on Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst for NH3-SCR previously. In the work, we report the preparation of SSZ-13 synthesized by using colloidal silica (silica sol), gelatinous silica (silica gel) and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) as silica source. Structure and morphology as well as other physicochemical properties were studied by various techniques. The catalytic performances are discussed extensively according to the characterization results. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Cu-SSZ-13 synthesis The synthesis of Cu-SSZ-13 was carried out by referring previous reports [21–23]. The silica source, aging time and temperature were adjusted in synthesis. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) was firstly dissolved in DI water, following by the addition of sodium aluminate. The solution was stirred until clear. In the next step, the structure directing agent N, N, N-trimethyl-1-adamantyl ammonium hydroxide (TMAda-OH) (25 % aqueous solution) was slowly added under stirring, and the stirred solution was kept at room temperature until it became transparent. Then the silica source with desired amount was added to the clear solution. The molar ratio of the precursor solution was as follows: 10TMAda-OH:5Na2O:4Al2O3:100SiO2:2200H2O. The resulting mixture was aged for 24 h under stirring, then placed in a Teflon-lined autoclave. It was maintained at 100 °C for 12 h in a rotary oven, and then held at 160 °C for 72 h under a rotation (∼60 rpm). The sample powder was then collected by centrifugation and washed three times with deionized water. The product was dried overnight at 70 °C. It was then calcined in air at 600 °C for 8 h to form Na-SSZ-13. The as-synthesized Na-SSZ-13 was dispersed in 1 M NH4Cl aqueous solution at 80 °C for 12 h under stirring, to obtain NH4-SSZ-13 through ion-exchanging. The NH4-SSZ-13 was separated by washing with DI water and drying the resulting solution three times. Finally, NH4-SSZ-13 was ion-exchanged in 0.1 M CuCl2 solution at 80 °C for 8 h, then filtered, and calcined at 500 °C for 6 h to obtain Cu-SSZ-13. The final samples were denoted as CS-Si sol, CS-Si gel and CS-TEOS for Cu-SSZ-13 with different silica source. The fresh Cu-SSZ-13 was hydrothermally aged in 10 % H2O/air with 100 ml/min at 800 ℃ for 12 h, and denoted as HA_CS-Si sol, HA_CS-Si gel and HA_CS-TEOS, respectively, regarding to different silica source. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) were carried out on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker, German) using Cu K α ( λ = 0.15406 n m ) radiation with an angle of 2 θ from 5° to 60°. The date was collected at 4°/min with the step of 0.02°. The XRD patterns were compared with the reference date from International Center for Diffraction (ICDD) files. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (MERLIN compact, ZEISS, Oberkochen, Germany) images were collected to characterize the surface morphology and particle size of the samples. Elemental Cu, Al and Si contents were quantified using Varian 715-ES Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES). 10 ml HF (40 wt%) and 10 ml HNO3 (65 wt%) were added separately to a Teflon-lined autoclave, then 50 mg sample was dissolved in mixed solution. It was maintained at 150 °C for 24 h in an oven. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of the series of samples were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 system to perform the specific surface area, pore volume and pore volume distribution. The t-plot method determined micropore area and micropore volume. The pretreatment condition for each test was degassed at 300 °C for 3 h. The NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiment was performed on a chemisorption analyzer (AutoChem II 2920) detected by thermal conductivity detector. The sample (100 mg) was pretreated at 350 °C in helium flow (30 ml/min) for 1 h, and then the sample was cooled down at 50 °C. Subsequently, the sample was placed into an atmosphere of 10 vol% NH3/He until saturation, followed by He gas purging 1 h. Finally, the sample was heated to 700 °C in N2 at a rate of 10 °C/min. Temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen (H2-TPR) experiment was conducted on the same chemisorption analyzer (AutoChem II 2920) detected by thermal conductivity detector. Prior to each measurement, 100 mg of the sample was pretreated in a quartz U-tube reactor in argon with the flow rate of 30 ml/min at 350 °C for 1 h. After the sample cooled down to 50 °C, the temperature was raised linearly to 500 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min in a 10 vol% H2/Ar gas flow of 30 ml/min. X-ray adsorption fine-structure (XAFS) measurements were carried out on the beamline 1W1B of Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF), China. The BSRF storage ring is operated at the electron energy of 2.5 GeV with beam current of 200 mA. Standard sample used the pure CuO and Cu2O powder. Using a Si (111) double crystal monochromator, eventual XAFS date were collected at the Cu K-edges (8979 eV) in the transmission mode at RT. Prior to testing, the sample was ground with starch at a 1:2 ratio and compressed. During the EXAFS data processing procedure, the back-subtracted EXAFS function was firstly converted into k space and weighted by k3 in order to compensate for the diminishing amplitude because of the decay of the photoelectron wave. The Fourier transforming of the k3-weighted EXAFS data was performed in the range of k = 3–12 Å−1 for Mn-K-edge with a Hanning function window. 2.3 NH3-SCR activity test Catalyst activity for NH3-SCR was measured at atmospheric pressure in a fixed bed quartz flow reactor. The powder samples were pressed, crushed and sieved (40–60 mesh) prior to use. Samples were pretreated in pure N2 at 100 °C for 1 h before each test. The reaction conditions were set as follows: 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 10 vol% O2, equilibrium N2 and the total flow rate was maintained at 200 ml/min. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was calculated to be 30,000 h−1. The exhaust gas was continuously analyzed by an online Nicolet Is 50 spectrometer equipped with a heated low volume (0.2 L) multi-channel gas unit (2 m). The FTIR spectrum was collected from beginning to the end, and the results were recorded when the SCR reaction reached a steady state (about 40 min). NOx conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated by the following equation: N O x c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = NO x inlet - NO x outlet NO x inlet ×100% Where, NOx inlet represents NOx concentration in the inlet (NO + NO2, ppm). NOx outlet stands for NOx concentration in the outlet (ppm). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties The XRD patterns of the Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts with different silica sources are shown in Fig. 1 . They all exhibit a typical CHA structure with characteristic diffraction peak at ∼9.5, 14.0, 16.1, 17.8, 20.7, 25.1, 26.2, 30.7°, showing no obvious difference of diffraction peak position between the catalysts. It’s noted that the intensity of the characteristic peaks of CS-Si sol was much higher than those of CS-TEOS and CS-Si gel samples. The diffraction peaks (2θ = 35.6° and 38.8°), which results from Cu oxides (CuO and Cu2O) aggregations, are not observed on the three Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2 b, the characteristic diffraction peaks remain intact for the Cu-SSZ-13 samples after hydrothermal aging treatment. While the peak intensities of all samples are notably considerably reduced. It may be ascribed to the part damage of zeolite crystalline structure after hydrothermal aging at 800 °C for 12 h [9,24]. However, the crystallinity of Cu-SSZ-13 synthesized using different silica sources has different degrees of decline. It can be clearly seen that the severe decrease in the crystallinity of HA_CS-Si sol compared with its fresh CS-Si sol indicated that the structural damage was serious. And the XRD intensity of HA_CS-Si sol and HA_CS-TEOS was quite similar. The XRD peaks at 2θ = 35.6° and 38.8° were also not observed on the three hydrothermal aged Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst, indicating that the Cu oxide species did not appear. The SEM images and particle size distributions of various Cu-SSZ-13 are shown in Fig. 2. All samples show similar spherical particles with different regularity and particle size (Fig. 2, a1-c1). The CS-TEOS and CS-Si sol showed more uniform particle size than CS-Si gel. This is further illustrated by statistical particle size distribution (Fig. 2, a2-c2). CS-TEOS was much smaller than CS-Si sol (0.46 vs. 1.51 μm). In the meantime, a quite wide distribution is observed for CS-Si gel. After hydrothermal aging (Fig. 2, a3-c3), the morphology and particle size have little change, indicating the stability under treatment. It will be shown in next that the SCR activity also shows relatively slight change for the hydrothermal treated catalysts. The proposed pathways of SSZ-13 crystallization are illustrated in Fig. 3 . The nature of silica precursor plays a dominant role in the growth way, leading to the difference of shape and structure. The possible growth mechanism using different silica source is described as follows. The dissolved silicate was firstly obtained through TEOS hydrolysis, silica gel or silica sol dissolution by NaOH, respectively. Then the silicate connected with aluminum source (AlO2 −) to form small aluminosilicate fragments. Thereafter, these aluminosilicate fragments were arranged and assembled in a structured manner around the organic SDA to form a CHA cage at the nucleation stage of the solid-liquid interface [20]. The primary nucleus and subsequent attachment rearrangement are more likely to cause the formation of crystals having an irregular shape and/or rough surface features [25]. During the initial nuclei formation process, different silica sources dissolve and assemble to different sizes of primary nucleus in solution due to the different sizes of aluminosilicate fragments [18]. The crystallite size of these samples calculated by XRD was consistent with the assumptions in Fig. 3. Therefore, it is proposed that the primary nucleus have the order of CS-Si sol (97 nm) > CS-TEOS (73 nm) > CS-Si gel (63 nm) (Fig. 3, nuclei). The finer the dissolved silica fragments, the more uniform nuclei produced, then the smaller crystals of SSZ-13 was obtained. Because the increase in the size of the molecular sieve is proportional to the primary particle size of the silica source [26]. The initial particle sizes of the silica source (TEOS, silica sol and silica gel) were sequentially increased. Therefore, the final particle size is in the order of CS-TEOS < CS-Si sol < CS-Si gel (not too homogeneous). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured to study the porous structure of Cu-SSZ-13 samples (Fig. 4 ). As expected, all the samples show obvious type I adsorption curves indicating typical microporous materials. The looming hysteresis loop between adsorption and desorption curve may relate to the mesoporous structure piling up among particles. As can be seen from inset of Fig. 4, the mesopores of the three catalysts are concentrated at 4 nm. However, the mesoporous volume of CS-Si sol is relatively small, and the mesoporous volumes of CS-Si gel and CS-TEOS are similar, which is consistent with the results in Table 1 . The BET surface area and pore volume are listed in Table 1. They both showed the order for different Cu-SSZ-13 samples of CS-Si gel > CS-Si sol > CS-TEOS. The highest BET surface area (670.6 m2/g) and pore volume (0.33 cm3/g) appear on the CS-Si gel sample might result from dimensional inhomogeneity, which is favorable for particle compact stacking. The specific surface area (596.2 m2 g−1) and micropore volume (0.21 m3 g−1) of the CS-TEOS catalyst are smaller relative to CS-Si sol (613.8 m2 g−1 and 0.21 m3 g−1) and CS-Si gel (670.6 m2g−1and 0.23 m3 g−1). It should be related to the uniformly dispersed and small particles of CS-Si sol. The specific surface area of micropore-based materials is mainly determined pore size and pore volume, and the particle size contributes less. Metal cations exchanged in zeolites also reduce the BET surface area. In this study, the BET surface area of SSZ-13 without copper exchange is about 760 m2 g−1. Therefore, the BET surface area of CS-TEOS becomes smaller as the content of Cu exchange increases. At the same time, the Si/Al ratio and Cu content were analyzed by the ICP-OES technique and listed in Table 1. The Si/Al ratios are close to their theoretical values ∼12.5 used in the synthesis. The Cu content is within the range of 4.0–4.9 wt%, a bit higher than general reports [22,23]. But no obvious aggregation of CuxO was observed, suggesting the isolated dispersion of Cu ions. 3.2 H2-TPR The H2-TPR profiles are present in Fig. 5 . The calculated amount of H2 consumption is also listed in Table 2 . The fresh Cu-SSZ-13 samples synthesized with different silica sources show three H2 consumption peaks. It had been reported that stability of Cu2+ in different position in the zeolite plays a crucial role in interpreting TPR result [27]. Obviously, the three H2 consumption peaks of Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts exhibited three reduction behaviors, indicating three kinds of Cu species in the framework of CHA of these catalysts. Based on the previous studies [28], these samples produced one main region of H2 reduction peaks (Cu2+ → Cu+) in 100–450 °C, the reduction peak A (centered at 167–204 °C) is ascribed to the reduction of Cu2+ in the eight-member ring [29]. The reduction peak B (centered at 265–341 °C) is assigned to the reduction of Cu2+ partially hydrated Cu2+ or [Cu(OH)]+ in the CHA cages [30]. The higher temperature peak C (centered at 383–412 °C) in the TPR profile is due to the reduction of “naked” Cu2+ ions in the six-member ring (6-MR) [9]. Noted that the Cu2+ in the 6-MR (H2 consumption) of CS- Si gel (0.085 mmol/g) has the highest content, the second is CS-Si sol (0.054 mmol/g), and the lowest is CS-TEOS (0.030 mmol/g). The Cu2+ in the 8-MR will be close to the CHA cage and the Cu2+ near the 8-MR performs more active at lower temperature [31]. For the three samples, most of Cu2+ are ascribed to near the 8-MR, particularly in CS-TEOS (0.475 mmol/g) sample. These easily reduced Cu2+ ions are believed to have relation with excellent NH3-SCR performance in the low temperature range [32]. Comparatively, after hydrothermal treatment (Fig. 5, b), the H2 consumption peaks at low temperature all shrink, while the intensity of high-temperature peaks (383–393 °C) increase. It suggests that most of Cu2+ ions in 8-MR moved to near 6-MR, with higher stability. The HA_CS-Si sol (0.527 mmol/g) showed the Cu2+ ions migration obviously, partially due to its smaller crystal size with easy transfer of heat and water. However, there is no Cu2+ ions aggregation in the aging treatment, which has been seen in the XRD patterns and would be further proved by the XAFS characterization. 3.3 NH3-TPD Fig. 6 shows the NH3-TPD results and acid site distribution/amount of Cu-SSZ-13 with different silica sources. The acidity of zeolite in the results of NH3-TPD is one of the important parameters determining the degree of reduction of NOx by ammonia on a zeolite-based catalyst [10,33]. There are four NH3 desorption peaks over the three samples with the largest overlapped two peaks at low temperature. The first desorption peak (∼102 °C) is assigned to physisorbed-NH3 in the CHA zeolite framework (labeled A). The neighboring higher temperature peak (∼132 °C) is assigned to weakly adsorbed NH3 on weak Lewis acid sites (labeled B). The peak (around 334 °C) is assigned to NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (Cu2+ ions in ion-exchanged sites) (labeled C), conducing to NH3-SCR reaction [31]. And the highest temperature peak (around 500 °C) is ascribed on strong Br ∅ nsted acid sites (Cu2+ ions coordinated with zeolite and framework Al atom) (labeled D) [6]. Therefore, medium-strong acid sites serve as the main storage site for NH3, and more Cu2+ can improve the performance of NH3-SCR [31]. Furthermore, it can be concluded that the peak at ∼500 °C is attributed to the strong Br ∅ nsted acid sites introduced by the high dispersion of copper ions [10], no copper oxides existing as suggested by XRD and TPR results. Table 3 presents the quantified of NH3 desorption amount for samples. According to the intensity of desorption peaks of these three Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts, the NH3 storage capacity (NH3 desorption amount) was in the order of CS-TEOS (2.810 mmol/g) > CS-Si sol (2.608 mmol/g) > CS-Si gel (2.367 mmol/g). The intensity of three peaks (at ∼132 °C, ∼334 °C, ∼500 °C) appeared to be gradually higher for CS-Si gel, CS-Si sol and CS-TEOS, because acid content affects NH3 storage capacity of catalyst to a certain extent. As the copper content increases, the amount of NH3 physically adsorbed and adsorbed at weak Lewis acid sites gradually increased. More weak Lewis acid sites could improve low temperature NH3-SCR performance by intensifying NH3 adsorption, while more strong Br ∅ nsted acid sites may accelerate the oxidation of NH3 and produce N2O, resulting in worse high temperature activity [34]. 3.4 XANES To identify the local environment of Cu species, the samples were measured by X-ray fine structure (XAFS) spectrum. Fig. 7 a shows the near-edge XANES spectra at the Cu K-edge on fresh Cu-SSZ-13 with different silica sources. The main feature at ∼8996 eV is ascribed to isolated Cu2+. By comparing to the reference spectra (Cu foil, Cu2O, CuO), it is clear seen that the Cu in the samples with different silica sources is in a higher Cu2+ oxidation state rather than CuxO-like compounds [28]. The pre-edge feature appearing in 8976 eV is assigned to a dipole prohibited plane 1 s→3d transition in planar Cu2+ complexes [22]. Compared with the pre-edge feature of Cu2O, it could be seen that there is no pre-edge feature at ∼8982 eV of Cu+ complexes. The pre-edge feature at 8986 eV like CuO has not been seen in the three samples, which is assigned to a Cu2+ 1 s → 4pz +ligand-Cu2+ change transfer excitation [35]. Furthermore, there is almost no difference between the hydrothermally aged and the fresh samples shown in Fig. 7c, indicating the stable form of Cu2+. The Fourier Transform of Cu K-edge EXAFS in Fig. 7(b, d) further demonstrates the isolated Cu2+ ions in the cage, 6-MR and 8-MR without obvious CuxO species. This agrees with the XRD and H2-TPR results well. 3.5 SCR activity of the catalysts The catalytic activities for NH3-SCR of NOx over Cu-SSZ-13, including their corresponding NOx conversion and N2O concentration, are depicted in Fig. 8 as a function of temperature from 100 to 600 °C. The differences in catalytic activity of the three catalysts are observed from the synthetic Cu-SSZ-13 with different silica sources in the precursor. CS-Si gel exhibited a superior activity with respect to CS-Si sol or CS-TEOS at temperature above 450 °C for the NOx conversion. While CS-Si sol was better than CS-TEOS. In the range of 100∼200 °C, CS-Si sol showed a lower activity with respect to the other two. In the meantime, CS-TEOS performed a better low-temperature catalytic activity. Both CS-Si sol and CS-Si gel had a bit higher NOx conversion than CS-TEOS from 200 to 450 °C, exhibiting over 95 % NOx conversions. The N2O concentration in products is shown in Fig. 8b. The capability of the CS-Si gel and CS-Si sol to reduce NOx to N2O was similar nearly over the entire temperature range, and higher than that of the CS-TEOS sample. After the hydrothermal aging at 800 °C, there was an obvious change of NOx conversion in the 400–600 °C temperature range for all the Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts with different silica sources, especially at high temperature region (Fig. 9 a). Perhaps Cu active component migrates after hydrothermal aging (seen from TPR results), resulting in more N2O production [31]. The NOx conversion was in the sequence of HA_CS-Si sol > HA_CS-Si gel > HA_CS-TEOS at 400−600 °C range. The NOx conversions were similar for the three catalysts at 200−400 °C. The fresh CS-Si gel showed superior NOx conversion may be ascribed to more Cu2+ in the 6-MR, which is more active at higher temperatures, as well as the high surface area and pore volume despite its wide particle size distribution. But the irregular particles were liable to broken and grow up (see SEM image), causing the damage of high temperature activity of HA_CS-Si gel. In contrast, CS-Si sol exhibited outstanding hydrothermal stability and maintains most of the NOx conversion after the aging due to the uniform and proper particles. Following the hydrothermal treating, some changes of NOx conversions were observed for the three Cu-SSZ-13 at high temperature. Conversely, the reduction of NOx conversions led to the increase of N2O concentration. The formation of N2O was lower at 100−400 °C, but it increased at 400−600 °C for the CS-TEOS. The N2O production of CS-Si sol and CS-Si gel was similar. Three HA_Cu-SSZ-13 synthesized by using different silica sources had the same low temperature catalytic activity, and CS-Si sol had the most excellent hydrothermal stability under the reaction conditions. Although CS-TEOS had the highest Cu content, for molecular sieves, excessive loading of Cu may reduce the structural stability of SSZ-13 [31]. As reported above, the Cu-SSZ-13 with different silica sources, namely silica sol, silica gel and TEOS, were synthesized accordingly. The silica source influenced the initial nuclei and particle size. The specific surface area and pore volume of the CS-TEOS catalyst were lower in comparison to CS-Si sol and CS-Si gel, which indicates that the CS-Si sol and CS-Si gel are relatively favorable for the SCR reaction, and thus the activity of NH3-SCR can be improved. Noted that the Cu2+ located in or near the 6-MR (H2 consumption amount) of CS- Si gel was higher than those of CS-Si sol and CS-TEOS. Since Cu2+ in the 6-MR is responsible for more active sites at higher temperatures [31], CS-Si gel has superior high-temperature (>400 °C) catalytic activity in as-synthesized fresh state. Furthermore, the relatively high NOx conversion on CS-TEOS at low reaction temperature is due to the fact that Cu2+ in the 8-MR will be close to the CHA cage and performs more active at lower temperature [31], resulting from the easy redox behavior of these Cu2+ ions [32]. As the copper content increases, the amount of NH3 physically adsorbed and adsorbed at weak Lewis acid sites gradually increased. More weak Lewis acid sites could improve low temperature NH3-SCR performance, while more strong Br ∅ nsted acid sites may accelerate the oxidation of NH3 and produce N2O, resulting in worse high temperature activity [34]. The NH3-TPD peak at ∼500 °C (NH3 desorption amount and peak position) of CS-Si gel (0.352 mmol/g) was obviously lower than CS-TEOS (0.420 mmol/g) and CS-Si sol (0.399 mmol/g), which speculates that the strength of strong Br ∅ nsted acid site is weaker and the copper specials is unstable [10]. That’s why the high-temperature catalytic activity of CS-Si gel was the best while CS-TEOS was the worse. After the hydrothermal aging, the main reduction peak of three Cu-SSZ-13 shifted to higher temperature, indicating that a part of Cu2+ in the 8-MR move to the 6-MR, and resulting in the increase of Cu2+ in 6-MR. With the increase of the Cu2+ in the 6-MR (H2 consumption amount), the high-temperature NH3-SCR activity increases significantly. Thus, the high-temperature catalytic activity of HA_CS-Si sol was the best, followed by HA_CS-Si gel and HA_CS-TEOS. Both fresh CS-Si sol and HA_CS-Si sol catalysts exhibited homogeneous crystal particles, as well as superior SCR activity and hydrothermal stability. Considering the cost and availability, silica sol is more profitable as silica source in synthesizing Cu-SSZ-13. 4 Conclusions In this study, effect of silica source (silica sol, silica gel and TEOS) on the structure and properties of synthetic SSZ-13 were explored. The CS-TEOS and CS-Si sol showed more uniform size than CS-Si gel. The samples exhibited regular morphology and excellent particle dispersions prepared by using silica sol. CS-Si sol and CS-Si gel showed high BET surface area, which indicates that the CS-Si sol and CS-Si gel are relatively favorable for the diffusion of the reactants, and thus the activity and selectivity of NH3-SCR can be improved. Silica sources affected copper species and content, acid sites and distribution of Cu-SSZ-13. For the CS-TEOS catalysts, the low-temperature (<200 °C) catalytic activity showed obvious advantages in three samples with more weak acid sites. While more strong acid sites may accelerate the oxidation of NH3 and produce N2O, resulting in worse high temperature activity. Furthermore, CS-Si sol had more Cu2+ ions in six-member ring, and the resulting CS-Si sol displayed superior hydrothermal stability. coredata.dc:description: In this work, we report the synthesis of crystalline Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst by using different silica sources, including colloidal silica (silica sol), gelatinous silica (silica gel) and tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS). These samples were characterized by various techniques (SEM, XRD, BET, ICP-OES, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, XAFS). The sample prepared by using silica sol exhibited regular morphology and uniform particle dispersions. The results also showed that different acidities and Cu ions distributions were present on these Cu-SSZ-13 catalysts. The various silica sources affected the physicochemical properties and subsequent catalytic performances in the selective catalytic reduction of NO by NH3 (NO-SCR). Cu-SSZ-13 from TEOS showed obvious advantage for the catalytic activity at low-temperature region (< 200 °C). However, Cu-SSZ-13 from silica gel performed superior overall catalytic activity (200–600 °C) in the three samples. Furthermore, Cu-SSZ-13 from silica sol displayed superior hydrothermal stability after the same hydrothermal treatment for the three samples, despite of the similar movement of Cu2+ ions under aging process. Thus, the choice of silica sol as precursor source is more profitable for synthesis of Cu-SSZ-13.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst by using different silica sources for NO-SCR by NH3
